messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 57 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On Approximability of Steiner Tree in â„“_ğ‘-metrics

Paper Abstract: Abstract In the Continuous Steiner Tree problem (ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST}), we are given as input a set of points (called terminals) in a metric space and ask for the minimum-cost tree connecting them. Additional points (called Steiner points) from the metric space can be introduced as nodes in the solution. In the Discrete Steiner Tree problem (ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST}), we are given in addition to the terminals, a set of facilities, and any solution tree connecting the terminals can only contain the Steiner points from this set of facilities. Trevisan [SICOMPâ€™00] showed that ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} and ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} are ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hard when the input lies in the â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1}-metric (and Hamming metric). ChlebÃ­k and ChlebÃ­kovÃ¡ [TCSâ€™08] showed that ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} is ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{NP}-hard to approximate to factor of 96/95â‰ˆ1.0196951.0196/95\approx 1.01 in the graph metric (and consequently â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}-metric). Prior to this work, it was unclear if ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} and ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} are ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hard in essentially every other popular metric! In this work, we prove that ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} is ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hard in every â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{p}-metric. We also prove that ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} is ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hard in the â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}-metric. Finally, we relate ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} and ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST}, by observing a gap preserving reduction from ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} to ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} in â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{p}-metrics. It is known that the ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hardness of ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} in â„“0,â„“1subscriptâ„“0subscriptâ„“1\ell_{0},\ell_{1}, and â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}-metrics can be obtained from the ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hardness of covering problems (with additional structure). Our main conceptual insight is that for certain ranges of pğ‘p (such as p=2ğ‘2p=2), the soundness guarantees of covering problems might be insufficient to show that ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} in the â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{p}-metric is ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hard, but the soundness guarantees of a packing problem (with requisite additional structure) is enough. Equipped with this insight, we are then able to embed set systems into every â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{p}-metric, and, depending on the value of pğ‘p, our soundness analysis of the corresponding ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³ğ–£ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{DST} instance in the â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{p}-metric will use either the packing property or the covering property (or both) of the set system in the soundness case. Due to the discrete structure of the Hamming space, the ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hardness of ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} in the â„“0subscriptâ„“0\ell_{0} and â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1} metrics follow from similar methods. However, these techniques do not extend to ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} in other â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{p}-metrics. To show ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·ğ– ğ–¯ğ–·\mathsf{APX}-hardness of ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³ğ–¢ğ–²ğ–³\mathsf{CST} in the â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}-metric, we instead rely on the robust hardness guarantees of graph coloring problems. Concretely, we present a reduction from a graph GğºG on nğ‘›n vertices to a point-set Pğ‘ƒP in the â„“âˆsubscriptâ„“\ell_{\infty}-metric space, where the cost of the optimal Steiner tree of Pğ‘ƒP is exactly n+Ï‡â€‹(G)2ğ‘›ğœ’ğº2\frac{n+\chi(G)}{2}, where Ï‡â€‹(G)ğœ’ğº\chi(G) is the chromatic number of GğºG.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 57 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 57"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "On complexity of 1-center in various metrics",
        "Better guarantees for k-means and Euclidean k-median by primal-dual algorithms",
        "Polynomial time approximation schemes for Euclidean traveling salesman and other geometric problems",
        "The k-Steiner ratio in graphs",
        "Near-linear time approximation schemes for Steiner tree and forest in low-dimensional spaces",
        "Steiner tree approximation via iterative randomized rounding",
        "On the history of the Euclidean Steiner tree problem",
        "An improved approximation for k-median and positive correlation in budgeted optimization",
        "An integer linear programming approach for finding deregulated subgraphs in regulatory networks",
        "Complexity of approximating bounded variants of optimization problems",
        "The Steiner tree problem on graphs: Inapproximability results",
        "Steiner trees in industry, volume 11",
        "New geometry-inspired relaxations and algorithms for the metric steiner tree problem",
        "Partition into cliques for cubic graphs: Planar case, complexity and approximation",
        "Steiner trees for the regular simplex",
        "A new bound for Euclidean Steiner minimal trees",
        "Steiner tree problems in VLSI layout designs",
        "Inapproximability of clustering in Lp metrics",
        "On approximability of clustering problems without candidate centers",
        "Johnson coverage hypothesis: Inapproximability of k-means and k-median in â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\\ell_{p}-metrics",
        "Approximation algorithms for continuous clustering and facility location problems",
        "The computational complexity of inferring rooted phylogenies by parsimony",
        "Disproofs of Generalized Gilbertâ€“Pollak Conjecture on the Steiner Ratio in Three or More Dimensions",
        "On the steiner ratio in â„›nsubscriptâ„›ğ‘›\\mathcal{R}_{n}",
        "On better heuristic for euclidean steiner minimum trees",
        "The Steiner problem in phylogeny is NP-complete",
        "The complexity of computing Steiner minimal trees",
        "The rectilinear Steiner tree problem is nâ€‹pğ‘›ğ‘np-complete",
        "Steiner minimal trees",
        "On the asymptotic behaviour of some towers of function fields over finite fields",
        "On Steinerâ€™s problem with rectilinear distance",
        "Steiner tree problems",
        "Discovering regulatory and signalling circuits in molecular interaction networks",
        "On the complexity of k-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "The steiner ratio gilbertâ€“pollak conjecture is still open: Clarification statement",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "New approximation algorithms for the Steiner tree problems",
        "Combinatorial algorithms for integrated circuit layout",
        "Solving Steiner trees: Recent advances, challenges, and perspectives",
        "Guillotine subdivisions approximate polygonal subdivisions: A simple polynomial-time approximation scheme for geometric TSP, k-MST, and related problems",
        "DCCast: Efficient point to multipoint transfers across datacenters",
        "The hardness of approximation: Gap location",
        "A new approximation algorithm for the Steiner tree problem with performance ratio 5/3",
        "Lecture 12 of Theory of Metric Embeddings",
        "A Steiner tree approach to efficient object detection",
        "Handbook of optimization in telecommunications",
        "Approximating geometrical graphs via â€œspannersâ€ and â€œbanyansâ€",
        "Hardness of approximate nearest neighbor search",
        "Tighter bounds for graph Steiner tree approximation",
        "A low-complexity algorithm for the construction of algebraic-geometric codes better than the gilbert-varshamov bound",
        "Algorithms for VLSI physical design automation",
